The same overall workflow is used for almost every commercial GM food, but MON 810 provides a publicly documented record that illustrates every safety‑assessment component.

---

## 1. What MON 810 is

| Feature | Description |
|---------|-------------|
| **Trait** | Production of the insecticidal Cry1Ab protein, which kills several lepidopteran pests (e.g., European corn borer). |
| **Genetic construct** | A single‑copy insert of the *cry1Ab* gene (derived from *B. thuringiensis* strain HD‑73) driven by a maize *Ubiquitin* promoter. The construct also contains a selectable marker gene (*bar* for phosphinothricin resistance) that was later removed in most commercial events; MON 810 itself does **not** retain a selectable marker. |
| **Regulatory status** | Approved for food, feed, and cultivation in the EU (2004‑2020, renewed after re‑evaluation), the United States, Canada, Brazil, South Africa, Australia, Japan, and many other jurisdictions. |

---

## 2. Safety‑assessment pipeline (as performed for MON 810)

### A. Molecular Characterisation

| Test | Method | Result |
|------|--------|--------|
| **Insertion site & copy number** | Southern blot + next‑generation sequencing (NGS) of the transformation event | One intact insert, ~1.8 kb *cry1Ab* cassette, integrated at a single chromosomal locus on chromosome 5. No vector backbone sequences detected. |
| **Stability** | Multi‑generational (≥10 generations) PCR & protein expression monitoring | Insert and Cry1Ab expression remained unchanged across generations. |
| **Protein sequence** | DNA sequencing of the *cry1Ab* ORF, translation to amino‑acid sequence | 100 % identical to the native Cry1Ab protein from *B. thuringiensis* HD‑73 (a protein with a >30‑year history of use as a biopesticide). |

*Why it matters*: Demonstrates that the only novel DNA is a well‑characterised, naturally occurring bacterial gene, and that no unintended DNA fragments have been introduced.

---

### B. Protein Expression & Quantification

| Test | Method | Typical expression level in grain |
|------|--------|----------------------------------|
| **ELISA** (enzyme‑linked immunosorbent assay) | Antibody‑based quantification of Cry1Ab in mature kernels | 0.1–0.8 µg g⁻¹ fresh weight (varies with genotype, environment, and tissue). |
| **Mass spectrometry (LC‑MS/MS)** | Confirmation of identity and post‑translational modifications | Confirms the Cry1Ab peptide pattern matches the reference protein. |

*Result*: Cry1Ab is present at **very low concentrations** compared with the dose used in toxicology studies (see below).  

---

### C. Compositional Equivalence

| Analyte | Method | Comparison (GM vs. non‑GM near‑isogenic control) |
|---------|--------|---------------------------------------------------|
| **Macronutrients** (protein, starch, fat) | Standard AOAC (Association of Official Analytical Chemists) methods | No statistically significant differences after accounting for natural variation among conventional hybrids. |
| **Vitamins & minerals** | HPLC, ICP‑MS | Within the range of conventional varieties; no new vitamins/minerals introduced. |
| **Anti‑nutrients / natural toxins** (e.g., phytic acid, fumonisin, aflatoxin) | HPLC, ELISA | No increase; in fact, some field trials reported *lower* fumonisin levels because pest damage (which promotes fungal infection) was reduced. |
| **Secondary metabolites** (phenolics, flavonoids) | Metabolomics (GC‑MS/LC‑MS) | No novel metabolites detected; overall profile overlaps with the conventional reference set. |

*Regulatory conclusion*: MON 810 is **substantially equivalent** to conventional maize for all measured components.
